snippet: High unemployment and violence continue to affect more than 7 of 10 American Indians now living in urban areas, according to new Census Bureau data.
abstract: New Census Bureau data finds more than 7 of 10 American Indians now live in urban areas, compared with 45 percent in 1970; migration goes to heart of question of whether reservations in United States are imperative or hindrance to Native Americans; tribal street gangs have proliferated in cities, and greater proportion of Indians live in poverty than any other group.
lead_paragraph: High unemployment and violence continue to affect more than 7 of 10 American Indians now living in urban areas, according to new Census Bureau data.

headline.seo: As American Indians Move to Cities, Old and New Challenges Follow
headline.main: Quietly, Indians Reshape Cities and Reservations
headline.print_headline: Quietly, Indians Reshape Cities And Reservations
